newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL interbank rates steady in thin market.
newsitem.headline: KL interbank rates steady in thin market.

text.p: Interbank rates were mostly unchanged in Kuala Lumpur as a liquidity crunch continued to pressure the market, dealers said on Tuesday.
They said foreign banks had some excess funds, but it was not helping to ease the tightness in the market.
"Money is in certain sectors, not in all tenures," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
"The bids are in a very wide range. Bidders are mainly smaller names (small financial institutions) and offers are from mainly foreign banks," he said.
He said medium-sized commercial banks were well squared up.
Dealers said internal restrictions on foreign banks did not allow them to lend to many borrowers in the market considered higher risk, like small finance companies and merchant banks.
One-week money was at 8.50/60 percent, two-week to one-month at 8.40/50 percent and three-month at 8.00/20 percent were all unchanged from Monday.
The overnight rate, which fell to around 7.0 percent, after mostly trading around 9.0 percent on Monday, was expected to remain at the higher end of the range, dealers said.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were down across the board on the expectation of a further rise in interest rates, futures dealers said.
At 0420 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) June contract was down seven points to 91.99, or an implied yield of 8.01 percent.
September contract was down seven at 92.33, or 7.67 percent, December was down four at 92.48, or 7.52 percent, and March 1998 was down six at 92.54, or 7.46 percent.
